context: Database access control deals with controlling <a0_0><b3_0>who (a person or a certain computer program) is allowed to access what information<a0_0/> in the database<b3_0/>. The information may comprise specific database objects (e.g., <a1_0><b4_0>record types, specific records, data structures<b4_0/><a1_0/>), certain computations over certain objects (e.g., query types, or specific queries), or utilizing specific access paths to the former (e.g., using specific indexes or other data structures to access information). Database access controls are set by <a2_0><b5_0><b6_0>special authorized (by the database owner) personnel<b6_0/><b5_0/><a2_0/> that uses dedicated protected security DBMS interfaces.
